seo.title: Positano in Winter on a Budget
seo.description: What’s open, how to get around, and ways to enjoy Positano in winter without overspending.

linkLabel: Positano in Winter on a Budget
intro: Winter in Positano is calm, affordable, and cooler. Use this guide to find what stays open, get around when ferries pause, and plan cosy experiences without overspending.
Pack layers (a lightweight down jacket plus a waterproof shell) and shoes with grip—staircases can be slick after rain.

sections.title: What stays open
body: Core grocery shops, cafés around Piazza dei Mulini, and the hostel bar operate year-round—expect shorter hours but reliable service.
Coast-to-coast ferries mostly pause November–March, yet SITA buses and select private shuttles keep running with reduced timetables.

sections.title: Getting around in winter
body: Use regional trains to Sorrento or Salerno, then the SITA bus; allow 20–30 minutes extra for wet-weather slowdowns.
Carry cash for bus tickets (€2–€3 each way) and bookmark the UnicoCampania app for last-minute changes when storms roll through.

sections.title: Budget-friendly days
body: Schedule museum days in Naples or Salerno on wet forecasts; round-trip train fares hover around €10 (approx. US$11).
Hike the Path of the Gods from Nocelle when skies clear: crisp air, empty viewpoints, and no summer heat.

tips: Choose accommodation with heating and breakfast included so you avoid extra café spend on chilly mornings.
Sunset is earlier (around 16:45 in December)—plan terrace time for late afternoon and pack a warm layer.

Call or message ahead via WhatsApp to confirm hours before you hike down the hill.
Daytime highs sit around 12–14°C (54–57°F). Nights dip to 8°C (46°F), so bring a warm mid-layer and socks for tiled floors.
